verses.verse: (He admonisheth by Jacob’s example to trust in God, and not in riches.) Ephraim is fed (That is, flattereth himself with vain confidence.) with the wind, and followeth after the East wind: he increaseth daily lies and destruction, and they do make a covenant with Assyria, and (Meaning, presents to get friendship.) oil is carried into Egypt.

The Lord hath also a controversy with (Which in those points was like to Ephraim, but not in idolatries.) Judah, and will visit Jacob, according to his ways: according to his works, will he recompense him.
He took his brother by the heel in the womb, and by his strength he had (Seeing that God did thus prefer Jacob their father, Judah’s ingratitude was the more to be abhorred.) power with God,

And had (Read Gen. 32:24-32.) power over the Angel, and prevailed: he wept and prayed unto him: (God found Jacob as he lay sleeping in Bethel, Gen. 28:12, and so spake with him there, that the fruit of that speech appertained to the whole body of the people, whereof we are.) he found him in Bethel, and there he spake with us.
Yea, the Lord God of hosts, the Lord is himself his memorial.
Therefore turn thou to thy God: keep mercy and judgment, and hope still in thy God.
He is (As for Ephraim he is more like the wicked Canaanites, than godly Abraham or Jacob.) Canaan: the balances of decree are in his hand: he loveth to oppress.

And Ephraim said, Notwithstanding I am rich, I have found me out riches in all my labors: they shall find none iniquity in me, (Thus the wicked measure God’s favor by outward prosperity and like hypocrites cannot abide that any should reprove their doings.) that were wickedness.

Though I am the Lord thy God, from the land of Egypt, yet will I make thee to dwell in the tabernacles, as in (Seeing thou wilt not acknowledge my benefits, I will bring thee again to dwell in tents, as in the feast of the Tabernacles, which thou dost now contemn.) the days of the solemn feast.
I have also spoken by the Prophets, and I have multiplied visions, and used similitudes by the ministry of the Prophets.

Is there (The people thought that no man durst have spoken against Gilead, that holy place, and yet the Prophet saith, that all their religion was but vanity.) iniquity in Gilead? surely they are vanity: they sacrifice bullocks in Gilgal, and their altars are as heaps in the furrows of the field.

(If you boast of your riches and nobility, ye seem to reproach your father, who was a poor fugitive and servant.) And Jacob fled into the country of Aram, and Israel served for a wife, and for a wife he kept sheep,
And by a (Meaning, Moses, whereby appeareth, that whatsoever they have, it cometh of God’s free goodness.) Prophet the Lord brought Israel out of Egypt, and by a Prophet was he reserved.
But Ephraim provoked him with high places: therefore shall his blood be poured upon him, and his reproach shall his Lord reward him.
